title: 108_hr3972
content: The Act titled "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" allows state social services officers access to federal databases for specific purposes. The "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" grants state social services officers online access to federal criminal history databases for conducting checks on individuals who resided with a minor during incidents of abuse or neglect. The "Protecting Our Children from Violence Act of 2004" allows state social services officers to access federal criminal history databases for investigating abuse or neglect of minors. Access is granted through a control terminal agency, and officers can conduct checks on missing persons or warrants. State social service officers can access federal criminal history databases for investigating missing children. They must share any information obtained with law enforcement agencies to help recover the child. Covered officers are certified by the head of a State agency responsible for social services. State social service officers certified by the head of a State agency can access federal criminal history databases to investigate missing children. They must share information with law enforcement agencies to aid in the child's recovery. Control terminal agencies are authorized criminal justice agencies with direct access to the National Crime Information Center network. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories or possessions of the United States. SEC. 3. The Attorney General must ensure that specific divisions of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children have access to the Interstate Identification Index, with officers meeting Federal standards for access. SEC. 4. Privacy protections are in place. Information obtained from checks or access under sections 2 and 3 must not be altered except for national security reasons. It can only be shared with authorized individuals or entities as required by law. Violating this rule may result in criminal penalties. Violating subsection (b) may result in imprisonment for up to 1 year, a fine under title 18, United States Code, or both.
